comments.commentBody: Not true at all. Spit was considered at least as offensive to the female ear at the time as feces.
It was Benjamin Franklin who bestowed the title "your superfluous majesty" on the office of the Vice President.

Perhaps similar to Biden's "stuff."  The moderator Radatz was funny, asking Biden to clarify what "stuff" meant.  All of America knew what "stuff" meant but the actual term is one of George Carlin's "seven dirty words that you cannot say on television," at least not during a Presidential debate.

This may be somewhat of a digression but I am pretty sure we were taught that John Nance Garner likened the Vice Presidency to warm spit because his reference to another bodily fluid was not something one talked about in mixed company.

"tough as nails but fair, superior fill"

Couldn't have said it better. Very rewarding to finish.
I had the SNAREDRUM in first, so I'm going to claim to be in my right mind, even though I put in SPERMDONOR without even thinking of BLOOD- or SERUMDONOR till I saw them here on WP...

Typical Barry Silk: tough as nails but fair, superior fill throughout, and not one single objectionable clue or entry.

Unless you count 12D, and I do not. My guess is, 12D was done on purpose to add an extra level of difficulty. No one in their right mind would enter it as a first choice. I had bloodDONOR, of course. Who didn't? It was the SNAREDRUM that set me straight.

I was discouraged to have the NW and SE corners completely filled with a few - very few - tentative guesses scattered around, and then having to stare at the vast white expanse between them for quite some time before entering another word.

But I stuck with it and *slowly* a few other letters helped me take a chance on LENNONMCCARTNEY. It worked! That gave me PAPER--C---ITER at 8D. Could it be, a mini-theme on Friday?

My favorite was the SEANCE clue, as well as the SECRET SANTA cross reference, and I normally dislike cross references.

What an absolute gem of a puzzle! Thank you, Barry.

Glad that Granderson had not one but TWO hits in this game. Sorry, Grandy, but you really did look bad games 1-4.

If the Yankees go on to win the World Series, they should give the Orioles a share. Wow! Those guys woke up and had the Yankees scared and focused the last six weeks. If Buck isn't at least co-manager of the year, injustice has been done.
Fist bump, Janice. Martha Raddatz was exceptional. It was most definitely a good show.

Gail Collins.....you are a good writer. I always enjoy your insights.

VP Biden was quite passionate. I admire that. Cannot wait for the SNL parody. The essentially unknown Ryan held his own even though Biden could be his dad. Gotta hand him that. And he has a strong bladder.

It did seem to me to be a bit like Crossfire more than a debate. But it opened the door for perhaps a more spirited presidential debate. I hope so.
I would like to see more fire from our president.

The moderator was awesome. She needs her own show.

I still suffer the after-shocks of America voting twice for George W. Bush. Twice! With all that we knew and saw and learned later - twice! It could happen again. Two wars, the collapse of the economy, a feckless Congress, a Court that decides elections and mistakes corporations for people, the unthinkable could happen again. There's still stuff lying around they didn't steal the first time.
Don't give up so easily.  Tenacity is required here.... The Republicans sure have it, so so can the rest of us.

I am not sure about that, Patrick. He has women, African Americans and Latinos solidly on his side, and a good measure of white folks to boot.

If this is racism by white people, and I believe that there is an element of racism in this election, then you can be cheered by the growing number of non-whites in this county who are happy to vote for Obama.

As a female, I cannot see how any woman would cast a vote for the GOP.

Biden did a workmanlike job of exposing many of the Republicans' lies, but I fear that it's not going to matter. The media is writing this narrative, and after the first presidential debate, it wrote in a plot twist according to which the Obama campaign's fortunes are sinking.

Moreover, I think that Obama is facing a mild drag from latent racism. It's so easy for some (many) Americans, when considering an African American person, to buy into the idea that "we gave him the job, it was a noble experiment, he's a nice guy, but it's just not working out and it's time for a change." This vignette is subliminally baked into the consciousness of many voters, and it's dragging on the president's numbers.

I fear now that this situation is not reversible, and I'm facing the grim, grim reality of a President Romney and a Vice President Ryan.
Why will it hit it's crescendo in 2 weeks?. Suppose somethinf else happens--like an Obama smack down of Romney in the debates? The voters have the attention span of a gnat and are fickle.

Personally, I am doubtful that the news coming out of Libya will push public opinion one way or another. The only voters still on the fence are the ones tactfully referred to as "low info" voters -- who tend to be extremely myopic when it comes to issues that affect them directly. The voters who know and care enough to track events in Libya have already made up their minds for either Romney or Obama.

I'm not sure I understand the value of the projection. It is so unstable it seems to be little more than an weighted average of the different polls.

To be meaningful the early projections need to reflect a final state. If Romney is at 39%, 15 electoral votes shy of a win, how was at 14%, 52 electoral votes down, less than 2 weeks ago?

The answer is simple, he wasn't at 14% two weeks ago, nor was he 52 electoral votes behind.

I did change my project this week, but it wasn't because of a poll. It was because of the House hearings on Wednesday that had clear requests for more security in Libya, a reduction in security in Libya with an increase in hazardous pay fee paid to State Department staff in Libya, and real time monitoring of the actual assault by State Department staff in Washington on both the phone and monitoring security cameras. Net, senior Washington staff knew what was happening as it was happening. To quote Biden, there is quite a bit of "Malarkey" coming from the White House.

My projection? I think the Libya scandal, which will hit its crescendo in about two weeks, will move Michigan, Pennsylvania, and New Mexico to Romney, moving him to 343 electoral votes.

I escaped the draft because of "bad" feet. My kids did not have to worry about it. The all volunteer army may be a good army, better than one from the draft, but with so few people likely to go to war, it makes going to war all to easy..
"We’ll probably never know what he thinks." - Ask him...he's on Twitter all the time.  Read his book, too.

Whenever I jump onto the NYT digital site, I look for Mr. Chivers (CJC) reports. For the most part, he reports dispassionately, rarely injecting his personal view(s). He gives us, from his perspective, the who what where why and how… which would be nice to see in other reporting on other pages/blogs in NYT.

CJC states: “The rebels remain woefully underequipped to fight the Syrian Army and Air Force.”

I can’t help but wonder if CJC uses the adjective *woefully* simply as a means to describe the level at which the *rebels* are armed compared to the Syrian military… or, does he use the word to describe his personal angst because he empathizes with and supports their endeavors? Or… a combination of the two?

Does CJC wish to see them receive more and heavier weapons… like the Manpads etc? What does he think of their Salafist and Wahhabist backers and the ever growing numbers of foreign Qaeda type jihadists filling their ranks? Does he think that the Syrian army was responsible for lobbing some mortars into Turkey... or was it the rebels? (in this incident, Syria has a great deal to lose, and the rebels have a great deal to gain by having Turkey go to war with Assad)

We’ll probably never know what he thinks.

I’ll be interested to read what he might write in regard to the chem/bio weapons that we’re all so concerned may fall into the hands of radical Islamists.

This article made me cry because it's so sad what horrible experiences can do to good people. All those things you wrote about .... The numbness, the depression, the terror and hyper awareness.... They exist for many people who suffer with PTSD. Thanks for putting into words what has happened to you. It helps people to feel less alone.

If the decisions did not come from or even with the knowledge of the President , or even Hillary. Then why would they fall on their swords ? Just so Weasel Romney can get his power fantasy fulfilled ?
If you want to assign blame, don't spare Ryan. He cut the State Department budget for security responsive to the needs of diplomacy.

I realize that Republicans have a hard time understanding that accurate and complete information from an attack takes time to become clear.  If America is unfortunate enough to have Romney become president he'll find that out, too.

The problem is not Romney or Ryan. The problem is the discrepancy between what Obama Administration officials claimed right after the attacks and what is coming out in testimony.

As tempting as it is to claim the buck stops with Romney, it does not. It stops with the president. Whether he decides to turn around and point the finger back at Hillary remains to be seen.

When I married my husband I left behind a successful career and went into business with him so that I could "be my own boss" once we had children. The children arrived sooner than expected and I found myself staying home more and more. Long story short, the business I had helped build was sold, my husband was head-hunted and developed a very successful career, My children flourished and I languished. By the time I tried to get back to a career all my peers had passed me by and I was in a similar position to the author. I think the answer, for the mother anyway, is to keep on working - whether it is best for the children I don't know but at least they would have a completely fulfilled woman for a mother.

Maybe we should see vice presidents and vice presidential candidates as engaging in some amount of selfless sacrifice by offering up acceptance of whatever anonymity or ridicule comes their way through their filling these roles.  That attitude might also protect us from the way Bush/Cheney used the office, especially during their first term, by screening out people if kudos are only given to those who keep to the tradition of the office of having a low profile while serving.

While I would never want to trade my husband in for a life as a single parent, I do find that having a partner makes it harder to teach discipline.  Often when I feel like I need to set limits or give consequences, I'm hesitant, not only because of my daughter's reaction, but also my husband's.  I bring over a decade of teaching experience to our family and so I'm just more comfortable setting limits.  Obviously, my daughter figured that out long ago.

Yes, and Id like to do that with a SNAREDRUM.

(Thought there was a WOK lying around, but that must have been yesterday.)

LeapyL, Apparently you placed that WOK on your back burner?

Howie
Excellent challenge, difficult but doable.  Barry Silk should be enhaloed.

Is it just me, or does TC continue to separate himself as the class act of the league? Between Harbaugh and Schiano, the Giants have already fulfilled their seasonal quota of playing against classless coaches, whose NFL population seems to be exploding. Having played the Jets in preseason, the trifecta has now been achieved.

To quote our fearless leader, "Talk is cheap, shut up and play the game."
I hope Biden's performance also sticks it to the people who are always saying we old folks are useless.
Ryan came across as vapid, at best

Whether the Biden-Ryan debate will successfully reinvigorate the presidential race or not it certainly reinvigorated a lot of Obama supporters. If Obama wins the VP debate will be seen as a turning point.

Not only was Biden articulate and relentless and able to use his many years of political experience to his advantage, Ryan was out of his depth. Like Romney, he has no specific proposals about how to reduce the deficit and the debt other than to rail against it and assert the Republicans will take care of it. Neither Ryan nor Romney has mentioned a specific tax loophole to be closed much less given estimates of amounts to be saved, all the while promising not to raise taxes on the wealthy. His only specific proposal - to "allow" those who will begin to turn 65 10 years from now to buy health insurance on the open market - is a terrible and unworkable idea. Surely, the health insurance companies love it. I don't think most people are fooled.

Certainly the many commenters on David Brooks' Friday column were not impressed with the "cool" younger Ryan or turned off by the passionate and feisty older Biden.

The VP debate in 2008 did not help Republican ticket either.

Sean
You are 100% correct. Today's debates are staged theatrics and it matters more how you look than what you actually say. In most cases the moderator is no more than a prop who asks a question that neither individual ever answers or is pressured to answer.
The Biden/Palin debate is the gold standard for this tactic. I don't think Palin answered any of the questions asked, she just gave a Republican talking points speech, however the so-called MSM pundits stated that her performance was great.
In any case, I doubt if any of today's debates influence the election.

These aren't debates. They're events played out for the TV masses. As an undergraduate I was involved in a number of structured classroom debates, and both sides had to do extensive research. There was tension, and decorum was sometimes lost, but zingers didn't do anything. What mattered was how well a person or team could structure and argument. We read the Lincoln - Douglas debates in order to understand how to compose and frame our positions. Our prime time political theater doesn't lend itself to this kind of depth, which is a shame.

If we got caught fabricating anything, we lost our arguments.
Same  conservative talking points.  Walking in lock step with no dissent is bad for any country or corporation; it is called group think. .

By the sound of your political bent, I would guess that you wouldn't much like the "good" Ambassador Stevens that you are holding up as this pure and wonderful martyr. He was a true liberal, through and through, who was a real idealist. And his naivete, as some others suggested, made him a little more careless than he should have been. I think this political haymaking over the issue is nauseating.

Stevens was supposed to be in Tripoli. He went to Benghazi to open a center and celebrate with the Libyan people.

Do you think that there would be this much condemnation of the administration if Stevens were not a victim in the attack?

Our embassies, consulates and diplomatic compounds have been targets of attack for years. The weakest link in a chain is always the most vulnerable and I suppose that never occurred to State Department security people who were more concerned with security at the embassy in Tripoli. Obviously, the entire State Department security team needs some basic training in security fundamentals.

While President Obama and Secretary Clinton may not have been aware of the security problem their coverup of the nature of the September 11 assault is inexcusable. It shows that militant extremism and hatred for the US is prevalent throughout the Middle East - even in countries such as Libya that currently have relatively good relations with the US.

The US simply can't afford to stay on the sidelines, as Obama is doing in Syria, and expect that his ridiculous policy won't foster more militant extremism, whether or not tied to al Qaeda, and won't come back to haunt the US. Good people like Ambassador Stevens end up paying the price.

I was appalled when I heard about Malala. And when I found our my student's father is being deported. And when a 10 year old girl was abducted in Colorado. And when my former student was gunned down in the street. And when a local teacher was accused of abuse and committed suicide....

The fact of the matter is, we are inundated with bad news: much of it outrageous and appalling. Every day. What do we pay attention to? I honestly believe that our brain, which evolved over tens of thousands of year of living in small bands of related peoples, is not equipped to adequately deal with this barrage of constant information from around the globe, constant demands for compassion for people we have never met and for whom we can do nothing (or almost nothing). We have to desensitize ourselves to a certain extent. Otherwise, how could we get up out of bed every day?

Does that mean we should not act when moved to do so? Of course not. But I don't think we should feel guilty when we don't act on every tragedy we hear about.

You left out the fact that this very same consulate had been attacked two prior times ... just months before this fatal attack.

Two former security guards threw explosive devices over the fence in April, while militants detonated an explosive at the gate of the consulate in June. Only the Wall Street Journal reported the attacks, and it only reported the latter one.

The Congressional House report also indicated that militants made a specific threat on Facebook against the late Ambassador Chris Stevens' life, causing him to stop his morning jogs when he was working at the embassy in Tripoli.

The House letter also says that multiple U.S. federal government officials confirmed they made repeated requests for better security in Benghazi, but their requests were denied by officials in Washington.

The war against terrorism is essentially guerrilla warfare. We, the US, are out in the open while those who want to harm us are in the dark. The time of any attack, the location, the planning is their choosing. We will learn from our successes as well as our failures and adapt our future strategies and tactics. It is not possible to predict all and to prevent all. There is a lot of talk about beefing up security. So we can send in say 20 people to defend. The enemy will know this and they will adapt their planning, they could decide to send in 100, 200 (in which case 20 folks will not be enough)  or they can choose another location, etc. Counter terrorism is always a learning process.
The Republicans need to fully fund Embassy security when it is requested then perhaps the State Department would not have to rely on local host nation security

Part of Issa's committee is composed of tea party member who can't find their way out of a paper bag. Republican Jason Chaffetz of Utah,  blew the CIA' s cover, but also on that committee is "dead beat dad" Joe Walsh, of Illinois, and other tea party members. This is the same party that has Michelle Bachman on the Intelligence committee.

If Mr. Romney wants to be sincerely indignant, as opposed to his phony indignance, he might talk a bit about how the committee Republicans blew the cover on some intelligence work in Bengazi by their shameless grandstanding on this issue, and Romney should be ashamed of his own efforts to capitalize on the matter, as well as pitied for his apparent inability to understand how an event in the Middle East might take several weeks (or longer) for us to fully understand.  He might also discuss what sorts of security improvements normally used for diplomatic missions would have been able to protect it adequately from a bombardment by mortar rounds and rocket-propelled grenades.  Somehow I think he doesn't know the answer to that.

Thank you for your eloquence. It is much appreciated.
I wish others could write about this tragedy the way you have. I'm sure the grieving families will appreciate your comments.
They just can't talk about that for some reason.  Good question though.
